qas.question: In what year did IBM begin to provide group life insurance?
IBM created a school house in 1933, what was its name?
IBM employees created a magazine in 1935, what was its name?
What program did IBM launch in 1942?

answers.text: program to train and employ disabled people

qas.question: What year did IBM hire its first black salesman?
In what year did Endicott provide group life insurance?
What was created by Endicott in 1932 for overseeing employee training?
What was held for female system service professionals in 1937?
Who did Endicott create a program to train and hire in 1942?
What was the name of the employee magazine in 1935 featuring the first black salesman?

context: IBM was among the first corporations to provide group life insurance (<a0_0><b5_0>1934<b5_0/><a0_0/>), survivor benefits (1935) and paid vacations (1937). In 1932 IBM created an <b6_0>Education Department<b6_0/> to oversee training for employees, which oversaw the completion of the <a1_0>IBM Schoolhouse at Endicott<a1_0/> in 1933. In 1935, the employee magazine <a2_0><b9_0>Think<b9_0/><a2_0/> was created. Also that year, IBM held <b7_0>its first training class<b7_0/> for female systems service professionals. In 1942, IBM launched a <a3_0>program to train and employ <b8_0>disabled people<b8_0/><a3_0/> in Topeka, Kansas. The next year classes began in New York City, and soon the company was asked to join the President's Committee for Employment of the Handicapped. In <a4_0>1946<a4_0/>, the company hired its first black salesman, 18 years before the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In 1947, IBM announced a Total and Permanent Disability Income Plan for employees. A vested rights pension was added to the IBM retirement plan. During IBM's management transformation in the 1990s revisions were made to these pension plans to reduce IBM's pension liabilities.
